Ye trees, does your foliage delay,</br>Refusing to veil with its shade</br>That spot — once so chearful and gay,</br>That cottage — in ruin now laid?
While others arise on the plain,</br>These walls in sad silence repose;</br>As never expecting again</br>Such social delights to enclose.
Fair decency, cheerful content,</br>By industry honest were won:</br>Here quiet his days Owen spent,</br>And counted these blessings his own.
His forge knew no weapons of blood,</br>Devoted to peaceful employ;</br>The stranger partook of his food,</br>Nor want chill'd the bosom of joy.
Yet, torn from his babes, and his home,</br>From his consort so fond and so fair,</br>He must change, for a prison's dark gloom,</br>This balmy, salubrious air.
Her infant new-born at her breast,</br>His Doro beheld him depart;</br>She sunk, with her sorrows opprest,</br>(Ah more — thou must ten times more smart!)
"And O if the lashes," she cried,</br>"My Owen be forc'd to endure,</br>With his blood if the scourges be died,</br>His life will sink under it sure!"
See her Owen returning again,</br>His neighbours all smiling around,</br>His innocence free from a stain,</br>And no lash has inflicted a wound!
How chang'd the glad prospect, how soon!</br>See the clouds of Rebellion arise!</br>The prison had then been a boon</br>Most grateful to Owen's sad eyes.
What, though from the maddening train,</br>As soon as he might he retir'd;</br>In his cottage resolv'd to remain,</br>While innocence courage inspir'd!
But innocence cannot avail,</br>When danger like this is so nigh:</br>This Doro, all weeping and pale,</br>Revolv'd, and implor'd him to fly.
For see, breathing vengeance and dread,</br>The disciplin'd armies appear;</br>The bands so tumultuous are fled,</br>And the cannon's dire thunder they hear!
But resolv'd in his cottage to stay,</br>In his cottage mild Owen they found;</br>Like furies they seize on their prey,</br>And his bosom receives the death wound.
The firebrands his dwelling invade,</br>The smoke — it ascends to the sky;</br>There innocence injur'd may plead!</br>There heard is the sufferer's cry!
Then Doro, her infants around,</br>Beheld her lov'd home wrapt in fire;</br>They heard the explosion's dread sound,</br>And in agony call'd on their sire.
Her stores by hard industry gain'd,</br>To rapine and flames were a prey:</br>But ah — if her Owen remain'd,</br>Of how little value are they!
She darts through the furious crowd,</br>Resolving his fate to explore:</br>She calls on her Owen aloud;—</br>She sees him — all bath'd in his gore!
Oh then, on his corse as she lay,</br>Her babe all unconscious beside,</br>In vain she invok'd the cold clay;</br>Her Owen no longer replied.
The warriors, reproach'd by her moans,</br>Their bosoms all poison'd with strife,</br>With insults reply to her groans,</br>And threaten her innocent life.
Oh what was her life in that hour!—</br>The load she had gladly resign'd;</br>Nor insults, nor threats could have pow'r</br>To quell the fierce pangs of her mind.
She lives for her fatherless train,</br>She lives, though her comfort is dead,</br>Chill poverty's gripe to sustain,</br>And strive for a morsel of bread.
Humanity weeps at the tale;</br>Yet frequent such scenes will appear,</br>Till Concord's soft voice shall prevail,</br>Which angels delighted will hear.</br>
